'''Shi Jianqiao''' ({{zh|s={{linktext|施|剑|翘}}|t={{linktext|施|劍|翹}}|p={{linktext|Shī |Jiàn|qiào}}|w=Shih Chien-chʻiao}}, 1905<ref name=fang/> or 1906<ref name=lean2007/> – 27 August 1979) was the daughter of the Chinese military officer Shi Congbin, whose killing she avenged by assassinating the former warlord [[Sun Chuanfang]].<ref name=lean2007>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gxG188kNRWUC|title=Public passions: The Case of Shi Jianqiao, Mass Culture and Collective Sentiment in Republican China|author=Eugenia Lean|year=2007|publisher=University of California Press|location=|page=|isbn=0520247183|pages=290|accessdate=2012-12-28}}</ref><ref name=lee2007>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Vhoh5nCHFZgC|title=Revolution of the Heart: A Genealogy of Love in China, 1900-1950|author=Haiyan Lee|year=2007|publisher=Stanford University Press|location=|page=|isbn=0804754179|pages=364|accessdate=2012-12-28}}</ref> The revenge killing and the legal proceedings that followed were highly publicized at the time and incited public debates over the concepts of [[filial piety]] and the [[rule of law]].<ref name=lean2007/><ref name=ocko2009> {{Citation | last = Ocko | first = Jonathan K. | last2 = Gilmartin | first2 = David | title = State, sovereignty, and the people: A comparison of the "Rule of Law" in China and India | journal = The Journal of Asian Studies | volume = 68 | issue = 1 | pages = 55–133 |date=February 2009 | doi=10.1017/s0021911809000084 }} </ref>
==Names== Shi Jianqiao's given name was Shi Gulan, ({{zh|t={{linktext|施|谷|蘭}}|s={{linktext|施|谷|兰}}|p={{linktext|Shī| Gǔ|lán}}|w=Shih Ku-lan|l=Valley Orchid}}).<ref name=lean2007/> She adopted the name Shi Jianqiao around the time she was planning to assassinate Sun Chuanfang to avenge her father's killing.<ref name=lean2007/> The characters of her adopted name mean "sword" and "to raise" alluding to her planned role as an avenging assassin.<ref name=lean2007/>
==Background== Shi Jianqiao was born in [[Tongcheng, Anhui|Tongcheng City]], [[Anhui]] Province, in the small village of Shazigang.<ref name=lean2007/> While her grandfather had still been a farmer and tofu seller, her father and one of her uncles rose to become decorated soldiers, which led to an increase in the family's social status.<ref name=lean2007/> She grew up in [[Jinan]], [[Shandong]] Province and had her [[Foot binding|feet bound]] as a young girl.<ref name=fang/> By the year he was killed (1925), her father had been promoted to director of military affairs in Shandong Province and served as brigade commander under the local warlord [[Zhang Zongchang]].<ref name=lean2007/> Zhang Zongchang and hence Shi Congbin were aligned with the [[Fengtian clique]], one of the two main competing warlord factions at the time. By some accounts, Shi Jianqiao graduated from Tianjin Normal College ({{zh|c={{linktext|天|津|師|範|學|校}}|p={{linktext|Tiān|jīn |Shī|fàn |Xué|xiào}}}}).<ref name=lean2007/>
In October 1925, during the [[Second Zhili–Fengtian War|second war between the Zhili and Fengtian warlord cliques]], her father Shi Congbin was leading a brigade of mercenary soldiers in an attempt to capture Guzhen, Shandong.<ref name=lean2007/> However, he found himself surrounded by troops of the [[Zhili clique|Zhili]] warlord Sun Chuanfang who had been leading a surprise counterattack against the advance of the Fengtian troops.<ref name=lean2007/> The next day, Sun had Shi decapitated and his severed head displayed in public at the train station of [[Bengbu]], Anhui.<ref name=lean2007/> Less than two years later, in early 1927, Sun Chuanfeng was deposed by the [[Northern Expedition]],<ref name=lean2007/> a military campaign by the [[Kuomintang]] that was targeted at ending the rule of the local warlords. He retired from his military career and founded the Tianjin Qingxiu lay-Buddhist society ({{zh|c={{linktext|天|津|佛|教|居|士|林}}|p={{linktext|Tiān|jīn |Fó|jiào |Jū|shì|lín}}}}) together with his former fellow warlord [[Jin Yunpeng]].<ref name=lean2007/>
==Revenge== [[File:Shi jianqiao pamphlet.jpg|thumb|right|Pamphlet by Shi Jianqiao authenticated with her fingerprint]] About 10 years after the death of her father, Shi Jianqiao tracked down Sun Chuanfang in Tianjin.<ref name=lean2007/> Shortly after 3pm on 13 November 1935, she approached him from behind while he was leading a sutra-recitation session at his lay-Buddhist society on Nanma Road.<ref name=lean2007/> She then killed the kneeling former warlord by shooting him three times with her [[Browning Arms Company|Browning]] pistol.<ref name=lean2007/> After the assassination, she stayed at the crime scene to explain her deed and distribute [[mimeograph]]ed pamphlets to bystanders.<ref name=lean2007/> Her case drew a significant amount of public and media attention.<ref name=lean2007/><ref name=sheng2009> {{Cite thesis | last = Shu | first = Sheng-Chi | title = Transregional Networking in the Chinese Journalistic Diaspora: Hu Wenhu/Sin Chew Jit Poh and Guomindang China, 1929–1937 | type = Master Thesis | publisher = National University of Singapore | year = 2009 }} </ref> After a lengthy legal process with two appeals that ultimately reached the Supreme Court in Nanjing<ref name=lean2007/> and pitted public sentiment against the rule of law,<ref name=ocko2009/><ref name=asen2009> {{Citation | last = Asen | first = Daniel | title = Approaching Law and Exhausting its (Social) Principles: Jurisprudence as Social Science in Early 20th Century China | journal = Spontaneous Generations: A Journal for the History and Philosophy of Science | volume = 2 | issue = 1 | pages = 213–237 | year = 2009 | doi=10.4245/sponge.v2i1.3511 }} </ref> she was finally given a state pardon by the [[Kuomintang|Nationalist]] government<ref name=lean2007/> on 14 October 1936. The assassination of Sun Chuanfang was ethically justified as an act of filial piety<ref name=lee2007/><ref name=he2010> {{Citation |last = He |first = Qiliang |title = Scandal and the New Woman: Identities and Media Culture in 1920s China |journal = Studies on Asia |series = IV |volume = 1 |issue = 1 |pages = 1–28 |year = 2010 |url = http://studiesonasia.illinoisstate.edu/seriesIV/documents/Qiliang_HE.pdf |url-status = dead |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120912133650/http://studiesonasia.illinoisstate.edu/seriesIV/documents/Qiliang_HE.pdf |archivedate = 12 September 2012 }} </ref> and turned into a political symbol of the legitimate vengeance against the Japanese invaders.<ref name=sheng2009/><ref name=he2010/>
==Later life and death== In 1949, Shi Jianqiao was elected as vice-chair of the Women's Federation of Suzhou.<ref name=fang> {{Cite web | last = Fang | first = Qian | title = 民国第一女刺客施剑翘 | trans-title = The Republic of China's first female assassin, Shi Jianqiao | publisher = [[Communist Party of China|CPC]] Zongyang County Propaganda Department | year = 2010 | url = http://www.aqzyzx.com/system/2010/05/27/002183237.shtml | language = Chinese}} </ref> In 1957, she was appointed to the Beijing Municipal Committee of the [[Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference]].<ref name=fang/>
Shi Jianqiao died in 1979, shortly after surgery for advanced colorectal cancer.<ref name=fang/> Her ashes were buried in the West Tianling Cemetery ({{zh|c={{linktext|西|天|灵|公|墓}}|p={{linktext|Xi |Tiān|líng| Gōng|mù}}}}) in [[Suzhou|Suzhou City]].<ref name=fang/>
